title: About This Catalogue
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Katharine A. Raff, Assistant Curator of Ancient Art, Department of Ancient and Byzantine Art

Katharine A. Raff, Assistant Curator of Ancient Art, Department of Ancient and Byzantine Art

Rachel C. Sabino, Associate Conservator of Objects, Department of Conservation

Lorenzo Lazzarini, formerly Professor of Applied Petrography and Director of the Laboratorio di Analisi dei Materiali Antichi, Università IUAV di Venezia, Italy

Karen Manchester, Chair and Curator of Ancient Art, Department of Ancient and Byzantine Art

John Twilley, independent art conservation scientist, Hawthorne, New York

Sandra E. Knudsen, independent scholar, formerly Associate Curator of Ancient Art, The Toledo Museum of Art

Sandra E. Knudsen, independent scholar, formerly Associate Curator of Ancient Art, The Toledo Museum of Art

Elaine Gazda, Professor of Classical Art and Archaeology, University of Michigan, and Curator of Hellenistic and Roman Antiquities, Kelsey Museum of Archaeology

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry2" id="curatorial_entry2">We recommend using the latest version of Chrome, Safari, or Firefox.

We welcome your questions and comments about the publication at OnlineCatalogueFeedback@artic.edu.

Due to the pioneering publishing platform of this catalogue, we are including the following citation guide for your reference.

Katharine A. Raff, “Cat. 1, Statue of a Young Boy: Curatorial Report,” in Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Art Institute of Chicago, 2016), para. #.

Rachel C. Sabino, with contributions by Lorenzo Lazzarini, “Cat. 1, Statue of a Young Boy: Technical Report,” in Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Art Institute of Chicago, 2016), para. #.

“Cat. 1, Statue of a Young Boy: Exhibition History,” in Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Art Institute of Chicago, 2016), para. #.

“Cat. 1, Statue of a Young Boy: Selected References,” in Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Art Institute of Chicago, 2016), para. #.

“Cat. 1, Statue of a Young Boy: Other Documentation,” in Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago (Art Institute of Chicago, 2016), para. #.

The following conventions for dating artworks are used throughout the catalogue:  
A.D. 117: Work created in A.D. 117  
c. A.D. 117: Work created sometime around A.D. 117  
A.D. 117/38: Work created sometime within or around the period A.D. 117 to 138  
A.D. 117–38: Work begun in A.D. 117 and completed in A.D. 138

All dimensions are given as height by width by depth unless otherwise specified.

Short citations are used throughout the footnotes to refer to complete citations listed in the Works Cited section of the catalogue. Sources cited in the curatorial portion of each entry are found in the Art Historical Sources, while sources cited in the technical report of each entry are found in the Technical Sources.

Artworks are referred to by italicized titles in cases in which an English-language title has been assigned by the institution that owns the work. Otherwise generic, descriptive titles (not italicized) are used.

Institutional inventory numbers are provided for comparative artworks wherever possible.

In the entries on coins, the die axis is expressed using the clock method. The die axis refers to the orientation of the obverse of a coin with respect to its reverse. When the coin is rotated around its vertical axis, the die axis is said to be 12:00 if the design on both sides is right side up, and 6:00 if the design on the reverse is upside down relative to that on the obverse.

The following standard reference works on ancient coins are cited in this catalogue.

Beckmann  
Martin Beckmann, Diva Faustina: Coinage and Cult in Rome and the Provinces, Numismatic Studies 26 (American Numismatic Society, 2012).

BMC Greek Antioch  
Warwick Wroth, Catalogue of the Greek Coins of Galatia, Cappadocia, and Syria, vol. 20 of A Catalogue of the Greek Coins in the British Museum (British Museum, 1899).

BMCRE  
Harold Mattingly, R. A. G. Carson, and Philip V. Hill, Coins of the Roman Empire in the British Museum, 6 vols. (British Museum, 1923–62).

BMCRR  
H. A. Grueber, Coins of the Roman Republic in the British Museum, 3 vols. (British Museum, 1910; repr., 1970).

Prieur  
Michel Prieur and Karin Prieur, A Type Corpus of the Syro-Phoenician Tetradrachms and Their Fractions from 57 BC to AD 253. Classical Numismatic Group, 2000.

RIC I  
Harold Mattingly and Edward A. Sydenham, The Roman Imperial Coinage, vol. 1, Augustus to Vitellius (Spink and Son, 1923). Revised edition by C. H. V. Sutherland, From 31 BC to AD 69 (Spink and Son, 1984).

RIC II  
Harold Mattingly and Edward A. Sydenham, The Roman Imperial Coinage, vol. 2, Vespasian to Hadrian (Spink and Son, 1926).

RIC III  
Harold Mattingly and Edward A. Sydenham, The Roman Imperial Coinage, vol. 3, Antoninus Pius to Commodus (Spink and Son, 1930).

RIC IV  
Harold Mattingly and Edward A. Sydenham, The Roman Imperial Coinage, vol. 4, pt. 1, Pertinax to Geta (Spink and Son, 1936).  
Harold Mattingly, Edward A. Sydenham, and C. H. V. Sutherland, The Roman Imperial Coinage, vol. 4, pt. 2, Macrinus to Pupienus (Spink and Son, 1938).  
Harold Mattingly, Edward A. Sydenham, and C. H. V. Sutherland, eds., The Roman Imperial Coinage, vol. 4, pt. 3, Gordian III to Uranius Antoninus (Spink and Son, 1949).

RIC V  
Harold Mattingly and Edward A. Sydenham, eds., The Roman Imperial Coinage, vol. 5, pt. 1, [Valerian to Florian], by Percy H. Webb (Spink and Son, 1927).  
Harold Mattingly and Edward A. Sydenham, eds., The Roman Imperial Coinage, vol. 5, pt. 2, [Probus to Amandus], by Percy H. Webb (Spink and Son, 1933).

RIC VI  
C. H. V. Sutherland and R. A. G. Carson, eds., The Roman Imperial Coinage, vol. 6, From Diocletian’s Reform (A.D. 294) to the Death of Maximinus (A.D. 313), by C. H. V. Sutherland (Spink and Son, 1967).

RIC VII  
C. H. V. Sutherland and R. A. G. Carson, eds., The Roman Imperial Coinage, vol. 7, Constantine and Licinius, A.D. 313–337, by Patrick M. Bruun (Spink and Son, 1966).

RPC I  
Andrew Burnett, Michel Amandry, and Pere Pau Ripollès, Roman Provincial Coinage, vol. 1, From the Death of Caesar to the Death of Vitellius (44 BC–AD 69) (British Museum Press/Bibliothèque Nationale de France, 1992).

RRC  
Michael H. Crawford, Roman Republican Coinage, 2 vols. (Cambridge University Press, 1974–75).

Unless otherwise noted, all overall high-resolution color photographs of the works in the catalogue were made by the Department of Imaging of the Art Institute of Chicago, Christopher Gallagher, Director of Photography, Louis Meluso, Director of Imaging Technology, and are copyrighted by the Art Institute of Chicago.

D. Young and Amy Zavaleta, in the Department of Imaging of the Art Institute of Chicago.

The majority of the technical details and UV images of the works in the catalogue were produced by Rachel C. Sabino in the Department of Conservation of the Art Institute of Chicago and are copyrighted by the Art Institute of Chicago.

Unless otherwise noted, all photographs appear by permission of the institutions mentioned in the captions. Every effort has been made to contact and acknowledge copyright holders for all reproductions; additional rights holders are encouraged to contact the Art Institute of Chicago.
